author: By Deb Amlen
title: Play It as It Lays
description: Lynn Lempel gives us a giggle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — It is always nice to start your solving week with an easy-on-the-head puzzle by Lynn Lempel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
title: Voters Believe Winner of Election Should Fill Court Vacancy, Poll Shows
description: A Times/Siena College poll showed that 56 percent said the next president should nominate a Supreme Court justice. And Joe Biden retained a clear lead over President Trump, 49 to 41 percent.
content: WASHINGTON — A clear majority of voters believes the winner of the presidential election should fill the Supreme Court seat left open by the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, according to a national poll conducted by The New York Times and Siena College, a sign of the political peril President Trump and Senate Republicans are courting by attempting to rush through an appointment before the end of the campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea Urges Joint Inquiry Into Official’s Killing at Sea
description: North Korea has apologized for the death of a South Korean government official, but the two countries differ on the circumstances that led to the shooting.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea called on Sunday for a joint investigation with North Korea in an effort to resolve key details over the killing of a South Korean official at sea that prompted a rare apology from the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman, Ken Belson and Elena Bergeron
title: N.F.L. Week 3: Russell Wilson’s Five Touchdowns Beat Dallas
description: Wilson was under pressure all afternoon but found receiver Tyler Lockett for three of his five scores against Dak Prescott and the Cowboys.
content: Last week’s N.F.L. lineup took out a fair number of notable players with injuries, while some surprising teams — the Chicago Bears, Las Vegas Raiders and Arizona Cardinals — got out to 2-0 records that have bitten some bettors. Of course, Week 3 is about when play starts to level off and coaches, even without the luxury of a preseason, settle into routine. Or not.In any case, contenders should start to take shape this week before Monday night’s matchup between Patrick Mahomes’s Kansas City Chiefs and Lamar Jackson’s Baltimore Ravens shows everyone where the championship bar is set.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 27, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 27, 2020.
content: An article in today’s paper about a series of killings on Long Island nearly a decade ago misstated the status of Thomas J. Spota’s sentencing for conspiracy. He has been convicted, but has not yet been sentenced or served time in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: We Don’t Need Debates
description: Trump will just make a scene and lie. What’s in it for voters?
content: The first column I ever wrote was about the April 2008 Democratic presidential debate between Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton. It took place in the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Mine Disaster in China Kills at Least 16
description: A fire led to excessively high levels of carbon monoxide, officials said. The site had previously been fined for safety violations.
content: HONG KONG — Sixteen people who had been trapped in a coal mine in southwestern China died of carbon monoxide poisoning, local officials said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Congress Needs to Help Tenants and Landlords
description: The president of the American Bar Association urges congressional action “to prevent housing instability.” Also: A president without honor; coronavirus testing.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: In Praise of PBS, a True Democratic Institution
description: Next month will mark 50 years of television that aims to educate and unite.
content: NASHVILLE — On Oct. 4, 1970, the Public Broadcasting Service entered the airwaves with an episode of “The French Chef.” I was not quite 9, too young for Julia Child and too old for “Sesame Street.” PBS became the television constant of my life anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Man Spent Donations to Black Lives Matter on Himself, Prosecutors Say
description: “There is no cause, no tragedy, and no event that fraudsters won’t seek to exploit,” prosecutors said in accusing a man of diverting funds from a group he ran that took in more than $450,000.
content: ATLANTA — The donations poured in this summer as Black Lives Matter marchers surged through the streets of Atlanta and across the country, protesting the use of aggressive force by the police and demanding more action to scrub out the deep stain of institutional racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: How to Keep the Coronavirus at Bay Indoors
description: Tips for dodging the virus as Americans retreat from colder weather: Open the windows, buy an air filter — and forget the UV lights.
content: As the autumn chill ushers people back into homes, classrooms and offices, the coronavirus may resurge even in states that so far have restrained its spread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: The Recovery Hits a Wall
description: Rising jobless claims signal a stalling economic recovery — and a long fall ahead.
content: If, like me, you’re deeply anxious about Tuesday’s presidential debate, here’s a distraction: all the business and tech news you need to know for the week ahead. Enjoy the rest of your Sunday. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Cream of Wheat to Drop Black Chef From Packaging, Company Says
description: The hot cereal joins Aunt Jemima, Eskimo Pie and other products that have shifted brand names and images amid calls for racial justice.
content: The Black chef will no longer appear on Cream of Wheat packaging where he was the face of the brand for more than a century, the product’s parent company announced in a decision that comes three months after it vowed to re-evaluate its marketing to ensure it did not “inadvertently contribute to systemic racism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: The Technical Stars Who Help Pull Off a Christopher Nolan Narrative
description: In films like “Memento” and “Inception,” the director’s time shifts and intricate action require careful calibration by editors, stunt performers and others.
content: “Tenet” is only the latest film by Christopher Nolan to play with time and complicated action. “Inception,” “Dunkirk” and the Dark Knight installments all aimed for new heights in tightly coordinated suspense and spectacle. But how do the makers of these mind-boggling films pull it all together?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: A New Zwirner Gallery With an All-Black Staff
description: The megadealer David Zwirner has hired Ebony L. Haynes to run a new commercial gallery.
content: The dealer David Zwirner has hired Ebony L. Haynes, a gallerist who is Black, as the director of a new exhibition program and commercial gallery space in Manhattan, for which she plans to employ an all-Black staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Panic! at the Disco’s Flourishes Weren’t Just Dramatic. They Were Theater.
description: A look back at the band’s 15-year-old debut, “A Fever You Can’t Sweat Out,” a commercial success that simultaneously satirized and celebrated staged spectacles.
content: Fifteen years ago, a mysterious top-hatted figure and a parade of circus performers interrupted a wedding in a music video with an unconventional soundtrack: an energetic pop-punk song with a bouncy, carnivalesque cello opening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: California Driver Charged After Striking Two Protesters, Police Say
description: The woman was charged with attempted murder and assault with a deadly weapon on Saturday, the authorities said.
content: A woman was charged with attempted murder after the car she was driving struck two people during a demonstration for racial justice in California that clashed with a counterprotest on Saturday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Hilary Moss
title: Fill Up on Tea or a New Film by Steve McQueen
description: This week, meet the singer Tashera Robertson, hit a photo show and try your hand at making snow fluff.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Arora
title: In a Book About Trauma, She Hopes to Show What Survival Looks Like
description: Fariha Róisín has been working on her debut novel, “Like a Bird,” for 18 years, a process she says has been key to her own healing.
content: When Fariha Róisín was 12, the idea for what would eventually become her first novel came to her in a dream. She didn’t have all the words for all that she wanted to say, but she started anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dean Baquet
title: An Editor’s Note on the Trump Tax Investigation
description: The New York Times has examined decades of President Trump’s financial records, assembling the most comprehensive picture yet of his business dealings.
content: Today we are publishing the results of an examination of decades of personal and corporate tax records for President Trump and his businesses in the United States and abroad. The records stretch from his days as a high-profile New York real estate investor through the beginning of his time in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Schram
title: Stars Beat Lightning in Double Overtime to Force Game 6
description: Corey Perry’s goal gave Dallas a 3-2 victory and stopped Tampa Bay from clinching its second Stanley Cup.
content: EDMONTON, Alberta — The injuries keep piling up, but the Dallas Stars are still alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: At a Pennsylvania rally, Trump said he’d have an edge if the 2020 race were decided by Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Phillips-Fein
title: Is Amy Coney Barrett Joining a Supreme Court Built for the Wealthy?
description: Future decisions by a very conservative majority could give corporations even more weight and workers less.
content: Much of the public anxiety about Amy Coney Barrett — judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, Notre Dame law professor and Donald Trump’s nominee for the Supreme Court — has focused on the question of abortion, and whether as a believer in originalism and a practicing Catholic she would be likely to vote to reverse Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough
title: Obamacare Returns as Galvanizing Issue After Ginsburg Death and Barrett Nomination
description: The health law had slipped in voter priorities, but the Supreme Court vacancy and November arguments in a case challenging its constitutionality have given the Affordable Care Act new urgency.
content: WASHINGTON — Less than six weeks before the election, the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg has injected fresh urgency into an issue that had dropped down the list of voter priorities this year: the future of the Affordable Care Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: With Nominee Set, Senate Republicans Plan Swift Supreme Court Confirmation
description: Republicans planned to hold four days of nationally televised public hearings the week of Oct. 12, aiming for a vote on the Senate floor by late October, just days before the election.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans began a furious sprint on Sunday to install President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, Judge Amy Coney Barrett, before an election just 37 days away, laying the groundwork for an extraordinarily swift and politically divisive confirmation battle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: With Wilpons Set to Cede Control, the Mets End an Era of What-Ifs
description: After his entanglement in the Madoff Ponzi scheme, the longtime Mets owner Fred Wilpon vowed to fight to keep his team. He did, but the scandal altered the course of his reign.
content: About six months after leading a pointed public battle against the Mets’ owners over their entanglement with the Bernard L. Madoff Ponzi scheme, the lawyer David Sheehan came face to face with one of them, Fred Wilpon, at Carnegie Hall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caren Osten Gerszberg
title: You Can Get Focused (Hint: Put Down That Phone)
description: The average person’s mind wanders nearly half the time. Here’s how to pull it back to attention.
content: The average person’s mind wanders 47 percent of the time, according to a 2010 Harvard study, so nearly half the time you’re doing one thing, you’re thinking about something else. Add the 24-hour news cycle, the barrage of social media and the countless distractions for those working from their bedrooms, backyards and walk-in closets — a number that has more than quadrupled from 8.2 percent in February 2020 to 35.2 percent in May 2020, according to research from the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas — and it’s no surprise that people are struggling to focus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: E.P.A. to Promote Lead Testing Rule as Trump Tries to Burnish His Record
description: The E.P.A. will tout a new rule on testing lead in drinking water as President Trump's latest environmental achievement, but water experts see only modest improvements at best.
content: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency is preparing to overhaul the way communities test their water for lead, a policy change that will be pitched ahead of Election Day as a major environmental achievement for a president not noted for his conservation record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Maggie Haberman and Jeremy W. Peters
title: Political Groups Begin Dueling Over Barrett in a Costly Clash
description: The battle may near $40 million in spending and will help define the end of the presidential race, even if Democrats are unlikely to be able to stop the Supreme Court confirmation.
content: WASHINGTON — The declarations of political war started coming fast as President Trump stepped to the podium in the Rose Garden of the White House on Saturday evening to announce his nomination of Judge Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: 2020 Presidential Debate Calendar: What You Need to Know
description: We’ve entered debate season, and here’s the who, what, when and where for the three matchups between President Trump and Joe Biden and the single vice-presidential debate.
content: Like many things this year, the presidential and vice-presidential debates will look a little different. There will only be one moderator per debate, and we’re still not sure if there will be a crowd — and, if there is, how many people will be allowed in. Each debate will start at 9 p.m. Eastern time and will run uninterrupted for an hour and a half, according to the Commission on Presidential Debates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: An heirloom tomato tart, a Sri Lankan dal and a crab and shrimp boil pasta: Set yourself up for success in the kitchen.
content: Good morning. The fishing guides are in Montauk for the season, cooped up in motel rooms, garage apartments, R.V.s, the cabs of their trucks at the inlet, all of them waiting on the tide, the wind, their clients, some auspicious combination that will allow them to get out on the water and in the presence of fish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Courtney Rubin
title: Movies and Museums Are Coming Back. Should You Go?
description: Cultural attractions are reopening across the country. If you decide to see a film or take in an exhibit, know the risks and take precautions.
content: Now that museums, art galleries and movie theaters are finally open in some states — with Covid-19 protocols in place — it may be tempting to race back to them. But should you?
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘My Girlfriend and I Wound Up in an Empty Dive Bar, Having a Drink’
description: Chatting with a bartender in Brooklyn, finding a family photo and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Coronavirus, Xinjiang, Supreme Court: Here’s what you need to know.
content: In the coming 24 hours or so, the world is likely to pass another painful milestone: more than one million deaths from Covid-19. India, the world’s second-most populous nation, leads in daily virus-related deaths, and the U.S. is second.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Solidly Conservative Record on Rulings
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 27, 2020.
content: “She is sympathetic to Justice Scalia’s methods, but I don’t get the sense that she is going to be a philosophical leader on how those methods should be executed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Associated Press
title: Banged-Up 49ers Make It 2-0 at MetLife, Beating the Winless Giants
description: A week after the 49ers beat the Jets at MetLife Stadium, then complained about the stadium’s “sticky” new turf, they dominated the Giants behind their backup quarterback, Nick Mullens.
content: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The way the San Francisco 49ers played on Sunday afternoon, missing quarterback Jimmy Garoppolo and several other starters was not an issue against the woeful and winless Giants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: New for This Pandemic French Open: Fall Weather and Lights
description: The postponement of the Grand Slam tournament from May created some significant shifts for the players and the event’s atmosphere.
content: The official poster for the 2020 French Open shows a view of a sunlit clay court through a dense ring of green leaves.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘How Climate Migration Will Reshape America’
description: “Might Americans finally be waking up to how climate is about to transform their lives?”
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison Herren Lee
title: Big Business’s Undisclosed Climate Crisis Plans
description: Companies know the U.S. economy’s large exposure to climate threats. Regulators can make them show their cards.
content: As the climate crisis intensifies, U.S. environmental policy has moved dangerously backward, with nearly 70 environmental rules reversed during this administration, and 30 more reversals in process. This intransigent, head-in-the-sand approach will not alter the reality of climate change, nor the risks and opportunities it presents the economy. The private sector understands this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: How Ruth Bader Ginsburg Lives on In Pop Culture
description: She found A-list fame late in life, appearing in movies, children’s books and ‘S.N.L.’ impressions.
content: Ruth Bader Ginsburg lived a storied life. In 1972, she became the first tenured female professor at Columbia Law School. In 1980, she was appointed to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. And in 1993, she became the second woman to serve on the Supreme Court, where she cemented her legacy as a crusader for women’s rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Do You Play Spelling Bee? Let’s Talk
description: Hive mind, unite!
content: I’d like to hear from all of the Spelling Bee players for an upcoming article.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Stenquist
title: 7 Things to Know About Your Used Car
description: Sales of previously owned vehicles are booming, but many new owners may not realize what they’re in for in terms of upkeep.
content: The pandemic has led many people to avoid public transportation in favor of walking, bicycling or driving a motorized vehicle. If the first two options aren’t practical, an automobile may be the best choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: Steven Stamkos Is Out for the Rest of the Stanley Cup
description: Stamkos, the Lightning’s captain and one of the league’s top scorers, made his only postseason appearance in Game 3 of the finals against Dallas after being out with an injury.
content: Tampa Bay will be without Steven Stamkos, its captain and top center, for the remainder of the Stanley Cup finals, Lightning Coach Jon Cooper said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Two of-the-Moment Monologues and a Multitude of Karens
description: One-woman plays by Tracy Thorne and Eliza Bent explore the problems of white power and privilege — and how people who say the right things aren’t helping.
content: Mary isn’t merely white; on a paint chip she’d be somewhere between “eggshell” and “iceberg.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noele Illien
title: Switzerland Votes to Approve Paternity Leave
description: Fathers will be allowed 10 days of paid time off after voters endorsed a new law despite a conservative backlash that forced a referendum.
content: ZURICH — Swiss voters on Sunday agreed to adopt a law mandating paternity leave, making it the last nation in Western Europe to do so and beating back strong conservative opposition to the proposal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Joe Montana and Wife Thwart Intruder’s Attempt to Kidnap Their Grandchild
description: A woman entered the Malibu, Calif., home of the former N.F.L. star on Saturday afternoon and took the child from a playpen, officials said.
content: A woman on Saturday afternoon entered the California home of Joe Montana, the retired N.F.L. Hall of Fame quarterback, and tried to kidnap his 9-month-old grandchild, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: By Lowering the Debate Bar for Biden, Has Trump Set a Trap for Himself?
description: President Trump has worked overtime to persuade followers that Joe Biden is addled and incoherent. That could backfire if Mr. Biden doesn’t fit the caricature.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump has framed the first general election debate as a test for his opponent, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano
title: How to Maintain Peace in Your School Pod
description: ‘It’s important to approach this with the idea that there’s no ideal situation. If there were, we’d all be doing it.’
content: Ivi Kolasi, a parent in Berkeley, Calif., didn’t expect that forming a learning pod for her 2-year-old daughter would take so long, or be so hard. In May, she began trying to find families with children around the same age as hers, and who adhered to the same level of health precautions. By August, she had developed a set of guiding principles for the group and located three other families, one of whom would split duties hosting the children with Ms. Kolasi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Suhasini Raj
title: As Covid-19 Closes Schools, the World’s Children Go to Work
description: Former students are taking illegal and often dangerous jobs in India and other developing countries, potentially rolling back years of progress in social mobility and public health.
content: TUMAKURU, India — Every morning in front of the Devaraj Urs public housing apartment blocks on the outskirts of the city of Tumakuru, a swarm of children pours into the street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Declan Walsh
title: Sudan Is Focus of U.S. Efforts to Improve Ties With Israel
description: The U.S. is offering cash aid and promises to entice Sudan to recognize Israel before the American election, while the big prize, Saudi Arabia, remains out of reach.
content: American efforts to persuade more Arab countries to normalize relations with Israel before the November election are focused on Sudan, where negotiations have stalled over the amount of a financial incentive promised to Sudan in exchange for recognizing Israel, officials said Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: There’s Gold in Them Thar Braes
description: With prices for the precious metal surging, amateur prospectors are fanning out over the Scottish countryside, while the nation’s first commercial mine is set to start production.
content: WANLOCKHEAD, Scotland — As a late afternoon mist rolled in over hills carpeted with purple heather, Alan Popovich stood knee deep in a fast-flowing river, weary but undaunted despite searching all day in the water without success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Trump Wants to Discredit the Election. This Nerd Could Stop Him.
description: Fox News, the president’s favored network, will face enormous pressure to call the election for Mr. Trump. The outcome rests on a little-known 65-year-old wonk who will declare the winner.
content: The Fox Corporation these days reminds me a bit of America: The elites have lost control, and partisan noise drowns out almost everything. But there are pockets where traditionalists cling to fading norms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Tony Tanner, Who Brought ‘Joseph’ to Broadway, Dies at 88
description: A versatile writer and actor as well as a director, he was also Littlechap in a film version of “Stop the World, I Want to Get Off.”
content: Tony Tanner, a versatile actor, writer and director whose biggest Broadway success was directing “Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat” in 1982, a production that helped make that musical a staple of American community and high school theater, died on Sept. 8 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth and David E. Sanger
title: Ransomware Attacks Take On New Urgency Ahead of Vote
description: Attacks against small towns, big cities and the contractors who run their voting systems have federal officials fearing that hackers will try to sow chaos around the election.
content: A Texas company that sells software that cities and states use to display results on election night was hit by ransomware last week, the latest of nearly a thousand such attacks over the past year against small towns, big cities and the contractors who run their voting systems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Judith Levitt
title: Amy Coney Barrett, Election Day, French Open: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and David McCabe
title: TikTok Wins Reprieve From U.S. Ban
description: A federal judge’s preliminary injunction means the app stores can continue offering the video app for downloads for now.
content: A federal judge on Sunday granted a preliminary injunction against a Trump administration order to ban the viral video app TikTok from U.S. app stores, in a reprieve for the Chinese-owned service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: Use the Renter’s Market to Your Advantage
description: If you’re hoping to relocate, renew a lease or renegotiate an existing agreement, this is what to keep in mind.
content: There’s nothing like being stuck inside for months on end to make you notice your home’s shortcomings, and stew about how much you’re paying for each and every one of them. Especially in places like New York and San Francisco — where rents reached record highs in 2019 — it’s now hard to justify top-dollar leases when you could be doing your job (and overseeing your kids’ remote schooling) anywhere. This, no doubt, explains the boom in suburban home sales since the pandemic began, and the corresponding exodus from expensive cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Storm Sweep Lynx to Advance to W.N.B.A. Finals
description: Breanna Stewart scored a career-playoff-high 31 points and Sue Bird had 16 points and 9 assists. The finals begin on Friday.
content: BRADENTON, Fla. — Breanna Stewart scored a career-playoff-high 31 points, tying Seattle’s franchise playoff record, Sue Bird had 16 points and 9 assists, and the Storm beat Minnesota, 92-71, on Sunday to sweep the Lynx and advance to the W.N.B.A. finals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2020 French Open: What to Watch on Sunday
description: Andy Murray and Stan Wawrinka face off in the first round, and Simona Halep starts her campaign for a second French Open title.
content: How to watch: From 3 a.m. Eastern to noon on Tennis Channel, and from noon to 3 p.m. on NBC; Streaming on the NBCSN app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Levine
title: For D.I.Y. Halloween, Make a Murder of Crows
description: Spooky birds are perfect décor for the season and can be created from your paper and some household items.
content: With so much macabre folklore and superstition surrounding them, crows and ravens are popular Halloween symbols of spookiness. You can create a flock — or, more accurately, a “murder” (of crows) or an “unkindness” (of ravens) — to decorate your home with just some newspaper, wire, tape and paint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 28, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Put Down Your No. 2 Pencils. But Not Your Face Mask.
description: The coronavirus presents a daunting new test for SAT takers, including our reporter, whose Princeton Review guides haven’t been cracked in years.
content: SLEEPY HOLLOW, N.Y. — Many of the teenagers pouring into the halls of Sleepy Hollow High School on Saturday morning, some still wearing their pajamas, hadn’t been inside of a classroom in months, and their lack of experience with social-distancing rules showed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Could Voter Suppression Affect the Presidential Election? Look at Georgia
description: A video series examining the vulnerabilities of our voting system and how they will impact the 2020 election. The first episode looks at unequal access to the voting in Georgia.
content: During Georgia’s June primary, frustrated voters documented long waits at polls in social media messages like this and this. Kevin A. Cronin captured the opposite — a nearly empty polling place in Sandy Springs, an Atlanta suburb. “Oh look,” he said after he put his absentee ballot in a drop-box, “no line at all out here in suburban white country.” Sandy Springs is 80 percent white. Mr. Cronin said he felt moved to start recording after seeing the hourslong wait at the more racially diverse polling location where his wife was voting. Drone footage captured lines stretching across the equivalent of football fields.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: 18 Revelations From a Trove of Trump Tax Records
description: Times reporters have obtained decades of tax information the president has hidden from public view. Here are some of the key findings.
content: The New York Times has obtained tax-return data for President Trump and his companies that covers more than two decades. Mr. Trump has long refused to release this information, making him the first president in decades to hide basic details about his finances. His refusal has made his tax returns among the most sought-after documents in recent memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: At Trial, Jewish Victims of 2015 Paris Attack Ask: Why the Hatred?
description: Four people were killed by a hostage-taker at a kosher supermarket that year. Families and survivors who testified  this past week said his callous anti-Semitism was still hard to process.
content: PARIS — It was a Friday afternoon, time for last-minute Shabbat shopping, and the Hyper Cacher — a kosher supermarket on the eastern edge of Paris — was busy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Why New Mexico’s 1680 Pueblo Revolt Is Echoing in 2020 Protests
description: Indigenous groups in the Southwest are imbuing their activism this year with commemorations of the 340-year-old Pueblo Revolt, one of Spain’s bloodiest defeats in its colonial empire.
content: ALBUQUERQUE — While protests over police violence against African-Americans spread from one city to the next in the aftermath of George Floyd’s killing in May, the missive scrawled in red paint on the New Mexico History Museum reached further back in time: “1680 Land Back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Social Media Needs an Election Declaration of Conscience
description: The platforms must not tolerate voter disinformation.
content: On election night in 2012, Barack Obama trailed Mitt Romney by some 30,000 votes at the moment Mr. Obama was projected to win his re-election bid. By the time the votes were tallied, Mr. Obama had five million more votes than Mr. Romney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Michael Crowley
title: In Critical Swing State, Trump Again Stokes Doubt on Election Process
description: The president has spent months falsely insisting — against evidence offered by his own government officials — that mail-in ballots are subject to widespread fraud.
content: MIDDLETOWN, Pa. — President Trump sought again on Saturday night to cast doubt on the integrity of the presidential election, telling supporters that the only way Democrats can win in Pennsylvania is to “cheat on the ballots” and raising the prospect that a disputed election could be decided by Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: LeBron James and Anthony Davis Fulfill Lakers’ Finals Promise
description: “When I first got here, he told me that he wants to give me my first ring,” Davis said. “And I told him that I want to get him back to the finals.”
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Purple-and-gold confetti fell on LeBron James late Saturday night as he sat on the court in a largely empty arena and digested the fresh reality that he was headed to his ninth N.B.A. finals in 10 seasons. One of the first people he thought about was Anthony Davis, his teammate on the Los Angeles Lakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Ashley Southall
title: Abrupt Police Crackdown on West Village Crowd Prompts Criticism
description: Videos taken of the scene showed dozens of officers rushing into a group of people near an intersection in the Manhattan neighborhood.
content: Dozens of New York City police officers charged into a group of people standing near an intersection in the West Village on Saturday evening and arrested several of them, in a chaotic scene that stunned outdoor diners and other onlookers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey and Karen Crouse
title: Wet, Windy First Day at French Open Pushes Players to Win Ugly
description: Coco Gauff and Simona Halep won their first-round matches. Victoria Azarenka did, too, but not before a rain delay. “I’m going to get frozen,” she said.
content: Sunday’s first-round match was certainly not the French Open debut that Coco Gauff envisaged when she won the junior girls title in the sunshine here in 2018 at age 14.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Fighting Flares Between Azerbaijan and Armenia
description: The governments of both countries reported action with tanks, military helicopters and artillery in a rapid escalation of a long-simmering conflict.
content: MOSCOW — Fighting that was reported to be fierce broke out on Sunday between Azerbaijan and Armenia and quickly escalated, with the two sides claiming action with artillery, helicopter and tanks along a disputed border.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Top White House Official Denies Pressuring F.D.A. on Vaccine Guidelines
description: The number of lives lost to the virus is nearing one million, and new hot spots keep emerging. The U.S., Brazil, India and Mexico account for more than half of the total.
content: The White House chief of staff, Mark Meadows, dismissed reports that he had pressured the Food and Drug Administration to soften new, stricter guidelines that the agency was preparing for the emergency authorization of coronavirus vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Patriots Turn to Burkhead and the Run After Newton Falters Early
description: New England struggled to get its passing offense going against the Raiders but got timely dashes from running backs Rex Burkhead and Sony Michel.
content: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — In the New England Patriots’ opening two games this season, quarterback Cam Newton’s offensive dynamism fundamentally transformed the look of the franchise. Newton led the team in rushing each time, dashed for four touchdowns and once threw for nearly 400 yards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fatima Bhutto
title: Pakistan’s Most Terrifying Adversary Is Climate Change
description: The country debates women’s honor inexhaustibly but pays little attention to the ferocious and imminent dangers of climate disasters.
content: Karachi is home. My bustling, chaotic city of about 20 million people on the Arabian Sea is an ethnically and religiously diverse metropolis and the commercial capital of Pakistan, generating more than half of the country’s revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Shepard Smith, Fox News Apostate, Is Starting Over at CNBC
description: In a new show on a new network, the anchor wants a ‘no pundits’ approach: ‘We’re not interested in helping you know how to think.’
content: Shepard Smith doesn’t have a bad word to say about Fox News.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinne Purtill
title: In Lockdown, an 86-Year-Old Blogger Finds an Audience and a New Purpose
description: Writing every day for weeks on end, she appealed to readers across the world. ‘That’ll be my role,’ she said. ‘To cheer people up.’
content: — Hazell Jacobs, 86, blogger
source.name: The New York Times

title: Gearing Up for a Battle Over Amy Coney Barrett
description: Readers offer different ideas about how the Democrats should act: accept the inevitable, boycott the hearing and vote, judge her qualifications, not beliefs.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Castillo
title: 3 Illustrated Novels With Animal Magnetism
description: With nods to “Winnie the Pooh,” “The Wind in the Willows,” “Frog and Toad” and “Charlotte’s Web,” three animal-centric novels help revive a genre.
content: Like most children learning to read, I leaned heavily on illustrations to help me understand and enjoy stories. Images provided a bridge to comprehension when words were little more than mysterious hieroglyphs. But as I became more comfortable with the words and moved on to chapter books and novels in upper elementary school, I missed that extra layer of story the art had provided.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Principals Assail N.Y.C. Mayor, Calling for State Takeover of Schools
description: The union representing New York City’s principals said it had lost confidence in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan to reopen schools.
content: The union representing New York City’s principals said on Sunday that it had lost confidence in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan to reopen schools and called on the state to seize control of the school system from the mayor — a drastic move that raised new obstacles to the city’s fraught reopening effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: In Maine, a Race About the Issues Has Become a Referendum on Susan Collins
description: Her opponent, Sara Gideon, is running on her record in the state — but does it matter in a year when all politics is national?
content: Two years ago Sara Gideon, the Democratic speaker of the Maine House of Representatives, announced that she was sick and tired of the partisan rancor permeating her state’s government. So she ripped up the seating chart in the 151-member chamber, the one where Republicans and Democrats traditionally glare at each other from across the room, and mixed up the two parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Futures in Peril: The Rise of Child Labor in the Pandemic
description: With schools closed and families desperate for income, millions of children are being forced into work that is often dangerous, arduous and illegal.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has forced millions of the world’s poorest children to halt their educations and go to work to help support their families, as schools have closed and parents’ incomes have fallen or vanished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Live, Urgent, but With a Slightly Recycled Feel
description: The British dance company Rambert livestreams a new choreographic work by Wim Vandekeybus.
content: In London on Saturday night, the venerable British dance company Rambert performed “Draw From Within,” a new work by the Belgian choreographer Wim Vandekeybus. I watched it from my home in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Russ Buettner, Susanne Craig and Mike McIntire
title: Trump’s Taxes Show Chronic Losses and Years of Income Tax Avoidance
description: The Times obtained Donald Trump’s tax information extending over more than two decades, revealing struggling properties, vast write-offs, an audit battle and hundreds of millions in debt coming due.
content: The Times obtained Donald Trump’s tax information extending over more than two decades, revealing struggling properties, vast write-offs, an audit battle and hundreds of millions in debt coming due.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Russ Buettner, Gabriel J.X. Dance, Keith Collins, Mike McIntire and Susanne Craig
title: Charting an Empire: A Timeline of Trump’s Finances
description: Tax records provide a detailed history of President Trump’s business career, revealing huge losses, looming financial threats and a large, contested refund from the I.R.S.
content: Tax records provide a detailed history of President Trump’s business career, revealing huge losses, looming financial threats and a large, contested refund from the I.R.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Officers Rush a West Village Intersection
description: Dozens of N.Y.P.D. officers charged into a group of people near an intersection in the West Village, arresting several. Video of the incident drew strong criticism that the officers had used unnecessary force.
content: Dozens of N.Y.P.D. officers charged into a group of people near an intersection in the West Village, arresting several. Video of the incident drew strong criticism that the officers had used unnecessary force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kassie Bracken, Alexandra Eaton and Noah Throop
title: Why Voting in This U.S. Election Will Not Be Equal
description: The first episode of our four-part series, Stressed Election, focuses on voter suppression in Georgia, where a growing Black and Latino population is on the precipice of exercising its political voice, if they get the chance to vote.
content: The first episode of our four-part series, Stressed Election, focuses on voter suppression in Georgia, where a growing Black and Latino population is on the precipice of exercising its political voice, if they get the chance to vote.
source.name: The New York Times
